qas.question: What two addtional types of birds are listed in teh Encyclopedia Britanica as poultry?
Who is the authoor of the book Poultry Breeding and Genetics?
What is the most likely outout for the common variety of pheasant ?

answers.text: frequently being bred in captivity and released into the wild.

qas.question: Edmund Dixon is most famous for what inclusions in his 1854 book on poultry ?

answers.text: peafowl, guinea fowl, mute swan, turkey, various types of geese, the muscovy duck, other ducks and all types of chickens including bantams

qas.question: Do all language make the distinction between poultry and fowls?

answers.text: many languages do not distinguish between "poultry" and "fowl

qas.question: What is the Japanese term for young pigeons?
What book did D. R. Crawford write?

plausible_answers.text: Ornamental and Domestic Poultry: Their History, and Management

qas.question: What is the Japanese term for "domesticated chicken?"
What is the only type of bird listed in the Encyclopedia Britannica as poultry?
Who is the jailed author of the book Poultry Breeding and Genetics?
What country has no birds that are considered poultry?
What word means the opposite of poultry?
Who wrote the 1842 classic book on poultry, Ornamental and Domestic Poultry: Their History, and Management?

context: "Poultry" is a term used for any kind of domesticated bird, captive-raised for its utility, and traditionally the word has been used to refer to wildfowl (Galliformes) and waterfowl (Anseriformes). "Poultry" can be defined as domestic fowls, including chickens, turkeys, geese and ducks, raised for the production of meat or eggs and the word is also used for the flesh of these birds used as food. The Encyclopædia Britannica lists the same bird groups but also includes <a0_0><b9_0>guinea fowl<b9_0/> and <b5_0>squabs<b5_0/> (young pigeons)<a0_0/>. In <a1_0><b10_0>R. D. Crawford<b10_0/><a1_0/>'s <b6_0>Poultry breeding and genetics<b6_0/>, squabs are omitted but <b11_0>Japan<b11_0/>ese quail and common pheasant are added to the list, the latter <a2_0>frequently being bred in captivity and released into the wild.<a2_0/> In his 1848 classic book on poultry, <b7_0>Ornamental and Domestic Poultry: Their History, and Management<b7_0/>, <b13_0>Edmund Dixon<b13_0/> included chapters on the <a3_0>peafowl, guinea fowl, mute swan, turkey, various types of geese, the muscovy duck, other ducks and all types of chickens including bantams<a3_0/>. In colloquial speech, the term "fowl" is often used near-synonymously with "domesticated chicken" (<b8_0>Gallus gallus<b8_0/>), or with "poultry" or even just "bird", and <a4_0>many languages do not distinguish between "poultry" and "<b12_0>fowl<b12_0/><a4_0/>". Both words are also used for the flesh of these birds. Poultry can be distinguished from "game", defined as wild birds or mammals hunted for food or sport, a word also used to describe the flesh of these when eaten.
